net.nand.util.i18n

Class PropsFileWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.nand.util.i18n.PropsFileWriter

  • public class PropsFileWriter
extends java.lang.Object
    Write a properties file out to disk, in the same format used by the jsettlers project: Valid ISO-8859-1 high-bit characters will be in the file as such, and not as \uXXXX code escapes, unlike Java's built-in Properties.store(java.io.OutputStream, String) method.

    Usage:

    • writer = new PropsFileWriter(File) or PropsFileWriter(PrintWriter);
    • writer..write(pairs, filecomment);
    • // Or:
      writeOne(writer, key, value, paircomment, spacedEquals);
      writeOne(...); ...
    • writer.close();
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>
    See Also:
    PropsFileParser

      Create a new PropsFileWriter using this open PrintWriter, which must use the "ISO-8859-1" file encoding.

      • PropsFileWriter

        public PropsFileWriter(java.io.PrintWriter pw)
        Create a new PropsFileWriter using this open PrintWriter, which must use the "ISO-8859-1" file encoding.

      • PropsFileWriter

        public PropsFileWriter(java.io.File pFile)
                throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                       java.lang.SecurityException,
                       java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException
        Create and open a new PropsFileWriter to this file.
        Parameters:
        pFile - Properties file to write
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - if the file can't be created, opened, or written, or is a unix special file
        java.lang.SecurityException - if write access is denied
        java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException - if the "ISO-8859-1" file encoding is somehow not supported; this is the encoding used by Java properties files, so it should be available; this error is not expected to occur.

    • Method Detail

      • isValidHighISO8859_1

        public static final boolean isValidHighISO8859_1(char c)
        For java properties file encoding, is "high-bit" character c valid in both ISO-8859-1 and ISO-8859-15? If not, it should be escaped (\uXXXX) in the output file.

        If a character returns true here, its unicode char can be output as its ISO-8859-1 byte: "ISO-8859-1 was incorporated as the first 256 code points ... of Unicode" -- Wikipedia ISO-8859-1 article

        This function tests only "high-bit" characters (0x80 and above): Any character below 00A0 returns false, including ascii characters which are valid in ISO-8859-1. Just use an if-statement to test the range 0x20 to 0x7E (' ' to '~') instead.

        In case of editing on a computer using the newer ISO-8859-15, the few ISO-8859-1 characters dropped from that encoding return false.

        Parameters:
        c - A non-ascii "high-bit" character, with unicode code point 0080 or higher
        See Also:
        Wikipedia: ISO/IEC 8859-1, Wikipedia: ISO/IEC 8859-15

      • appendEsc

        public static final void appendEsc(java.lang.StringBuilder sb,
                                   char c)
        Escape and append 1 special character to a StringBuilder.
        Parameters:
        sb - StringBuilder to append c onto
        c - A character to escape; \t \r \n and ' ' are appended as their 2-character text escapes, all others will be appended as \uXXXX (4 hex digits).

      • escValue

        public static final java.lang.String escValue(java.lang.String val)
        Examine a property value string, and escape any non-ISO-8859-1 unicode characters and leading whitespace.
        Parameters:
        val - Property value to unicode-escape
        Returns:
        Escaped val if escapes were needed, otherwise val

      • writeOne

        public static final void writeOne(java.io.PrintWriter pw,
                                  java.lang.String key,
                                  java.lang.String val,
                                  java.util.List<java.lang.String> comments,
                                  boolean spacedEquals)
        Write one key-value pair line to the properties file, making sure unicode escapes are re-escaped to \uXXXX where needed, otherwise keeping val unchanged and keeping high-bit ISO-8859-1 characters for easier viewing.
        Parameters:
        pw - An open PrintWriter for the output file; must have encoding ISO-8859-1
        key - Key to write; assumes no special characters to be escaped
        val - Value to write; leading whitespace and special characters will be escaped; backslashes will not be doubled, assumes they are part of an escape sequence in val
        comments - Comment lines to write above key=value, or null; each one must contain a leading "# "
        spacedEquals - If true, If true, the key and value are separated by " = " instead of "="

      • flush

        public void flush()

      • close

        public void close()

      • write

        public void write(java.util.List<PropsFileParser.KeyPairLine> pairs,
                  java.lang.String fileComment)
        Write these key-value pairs through the open writer.
        Parameters:
        pairs - Key-value pairs to write, same format as PropsFileParser.parseOneFile(File)
        fileComment - Optional single-line comment to place above output keys, or null; will prepend "# "
